reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “value is (approximately) a product of many (relatively) independent factors” move, which is an important support for the intuitive claim that mostly-great futures are rare, but it is not the only pillar: the essay also argues for fussiness via population ethics, digital minds, bounded/unbounded value-function considerations, and moral-uncertainty aggregation. So falsifying (near-)independence would weaken but not collapse the overall case (moderate centrality). The critique’s core point—that shared underlying drivers (e.g., governance competence) plausibly induce positive correlations across many ‘dimensions’, reducing the right-skew implied by independent multiplicative models—is a real challenge to the toy model’s quantitative intuition. However, it does not show the correlations would be strong enough (or broadly positive across the most decision-relevant dimensions) to ‘flip’ to easy eutopia; multiplicative fragility can persist under correlated factors, and some factors could be negatively correlated or governed by different causal levers. It also doesn’t engage the essay’s broader, non-toy-model reasons for narrow targets. Thus it weakens but doesn’t refute (moderate-low strength). It is highly relevant to Forethought’s agenda because they explicitly lean on multiplicative EV decompositions/product-of-factors across the programme and this is closely connected to their Tier 2 ‘narrow target’ framing; pushing for a causal/empirical story about correlation structure is constructive (high relevance). Overall, it’s a useful but not decisive objection.
title: Positive institutional correlations undermine multiplicative fragility
